isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 5000i and 9000i - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - TROUBLESHOOTING - VEHICLE CHARGING SYSTEM

svcsubproc.title: Batteries Undercharged
svcsubproc.para: Before beginning test procedures: check battery cables and alternator wiring (especially grounds) for clean, tight connections. Wires and connectors should not be damaged or corroded.
Perform the following checks before removing the alternator from the vehicle.

step1.para: Accessories having been left on for an extended time.

Check alternator drive belt tension (refer to GROUP 12 - ENGINE, Cooling in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for belt tension specifications). As a general rule, if the alternator fan can be rotated by pulling on the fan with one finger, the belt is too loose.
Inspect for defective batteries as described in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Battery Section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
Wiring defects. Visually check wiring, clamps, and connections for clean, tight connections, free of damage and corrosion.
With the engine OFF, check voltage to ground at the BAT terminal of the alternator. A zero reading indicates an open in circuit 2, between the alternator and batteries.
A defective component or wiring defect may be causing a small current drain that is less than the fuse rating for the circuit so the fuse does not open. To locate the unwanted current drain:

note.para: Batteries should be fully charged for the following test.

step2.para: KEY OFF- Turn all accessories and controls off. Disconnect circuit 2 from the alternator B terminal.

To check the entire system for current drains, insert the DMM leads in the COM and 10A fused jack on the meter. Set the meter to DC Amps. Connect the meter in series with the alternator (if the meter leads are not connected with correct polarity, a (-) amp reading will be present.
Some current draw will be present. If the current draw is less than 0.3A move the lead from the 10A jack to the 320mA jack to read the exact current flow.

Refer to the Battery Power Distribution circuit diagrams in CTS-5298 or S08225. Remove the battery feed fuses one at a time, while monitoring the meter for any change in current flow. Note that some circuits (such as clock or radio or engine computer, etc.) should be drawing some current. Look for current draw in circuits that should not be active.

step1.para: Perform Alternator Wiring Test.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Tests
svcsubproc.para: The alternator output must reach the batteries and accessory loads with a minimum amount of voltage loss. Any loss slows the rate of charge to the batteries and can cause the batteries to be undercharged. Discharged batteries can damage the starter and cause vehicle electrical components to operate improperly.

Most alternators control the maximum system voltage using a voltage regulator. Maximum voltage output is available at the alternator BAT terminal, but if any voltage is lost in the wiring, something less than the maximum will reach the batteries and load devices. The greatest losses occur when the charging system is outputting at the maximum rated level (amps).

Instead of using alternator current output this test uses the same amount of current but draws it from the batteries (must be fully charged). Using the carbon pile load, the current flows in reverse through the circuit without the engine running.

step1.para: Without the engine running, connect the carbon pile to the alternator output terminal and ground.

note.para: Alternator output is at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect voltmeter between alternator output terminal and positive battery terminal.
Adjust the carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Rated output is stamped on the case or on a tag.
Read voltmeter and record positive circuit voltage loss. Immediately turn the carbon pile off.
Move the voltmeter connections to between the alternator, ground and negative battery terminal. Adjust carbon pile to rated output (amps) of the alternator.
Read voltmeter and record negative circuit voltage loss. Immediately turn carbon pile off.

svcsubproc.para: If system loss is 0.7V or less, go to Alternator Replacement Test
If system loss is greater than 0.7V, repair circuit(s) with excessive voltage loss and retest. Then go to Alternator Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Replacement Test - Voltage Output Test
svcsubproc.para: If the wiring tests have been performed (circuits OK), adjust alternator belt and tighten mounting bolts and ground connections. Batteries must be near full charge with more than 12.4 volts no load voltage.

step1.para: With vehicle at shop temperature, connect voltmeter between alternator "B" (+) and "G" (-) terminals.
With NO electrical loads turned on, start the engine. Fast idle engine until voltage stabilizes (does not increase) for 2 minutes.
Check and record alternator output voltage _______V (should not exceed 15.5 volts).
If voltage reading is above 15.5V, replace the alternator.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Replacement Test - Amperage Output Test

step1.para: With vehicle at shop temperature, connect carbon pile and clamp-on ammeter as shown ( see Figure above). Clamp around all wires connected to alternator "B" terminal. (To use an ammeter without an induction clamp, disconnect circuits to alternator "B" terminal and connect meter shunt between alternator B+ terminal and all circuits previously removed.)

caution.para: Do not connect an ammeter without a high current shunt.

step1.para: With NO electrical loads turned on, start the engine, and speed up and maintain a high RPM.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile until ammeter reads its highest value and record ______A.
Turn off carbon pile and engine.

If reading is zero (no output), the rotor should be magnetized with the alternator hooked up normally. To do this, momentarily connect a jumper lead from the alternator "B" terminal to the indicator "R" terminal. This will restore normal residual magnetism.
Repeat steps 2, 3, and 4. If output is still zero, replace alternator.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Replacement Test - Replacement
svcsubproc.para: Replace alternator if either of the following exists:

item.para: Output current is not within 10% of the alternator rated output stamped on the alternator.
